danytaabe: Hi Greta. I don't know if you will read this but I must try. I am from Mendoza Argentina, the land that gives life to the best wines in the world. We are known and visited by many famous and great people of the world for the beauty of our land and the attractions of the inhabitants, at least they have told us. I write to you with all the humility I have and with the hope that you will listen to me and understand the great sadness I have been with my family today. My family is the whole town of Mendoza. and on December 22 we started a peaceful march, walking more than 100 kilometers until we reached the government house. We started on december 22 and arrived on the 23rd at 7am to the city. We marched because the Mendoza government approved the reform of the only law that protects Mendoza's pure water, giving the mining multinationals permission to use cyanide, sulfuric acid, among other things to perform the extraction of metals. Law 7722 was prepared to protect water, not to be against mining. We only wish that the mining that is carried out does not use the little water we have since it is used for consumption and agricultural production. Many people from my town marched to the capital through the desert and several more small towns. We are so many interested in protecting the water that eighty thousand people gathered who only carried water and a flag of Argentina. nobody represented a particular ideology, nobody was interested in anything other than the protection of 7722. law that was applauded in many other countries and admired. When we arrived at the government house, our governor Rodolfo Suárez did not attend us, he did not try to talk and nobody in his cabinet did. Families with newborn children, young children and grandparents with their entire families were part of a cruel repression that the government itself devised by placing infiltrators who attacked the police and they responded with tear gas and rubber bullets everywhere and sparing no people there they were. but we ... were many more! and we couldn't do anything to stop them. Help!

yonii74: Hi dear gretathu. I don't know if you will read this but I must try. I am from Mendoza Argentina, the land that gives life to the best wines in the world. We are known and visited by many famous and great people of the world for the beauty of our land and the attractions of the inhabitants, at least they have told us. I write to you with all the humility I have and with the hope that you will listen to me and understand the great sadness I have been with my family today. My family is the whole town of Mendoza. and on December 22 we started a peaceful march, walking more than 100 kilometers until we reached the government house. We started on december 22 and arrived on the 23rd at 7am to the city. We marched because the Mendoza government approved the reform of the only law that protects Mendoza's pure water, giving the mining multinationals permission to use cyanide, sulfuric acid, among other things to perform the extraction of metals. Law 7722 was prepared to protect water, not to be against mining. We only wish that the mining that is carried out does not use the little water we have since it is used for consumption and agricultural production. Many people from my town marched to the capital through the desert and several more small towns. We are so many interested in protecting the water that eighty thousand people gathered who only carried water and a flag of Argentina. nobody represented a particular ideology, nobody was interested in anything other than the protection of 7722. law that was applauded in many other countries and admired. When we arrived at the government house, our governor Rodolfo Suárez did not attend us, he did not try to talk and nobody in his cabinet did. Families with newborn children, young children and grandparents with their entire families were part of a cruel repression that the government itself devised by placing infiltrators who attacked the police and they responded with tear gas and rubber bullets everywhere and sparing no people there they were. but we ... were many more! and we couldn't do anything to stop them because there were families and it was a peaceful march. in fact it is the biggest march in Mendoza something ne
